title: Britain's booming special effects industry in the spotlight as DNEG considers London float
text:
Fifty years ago, it took 400,000 people to put Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin on the moon. Last year DNEG managed to do it with just over 550.

DNEG didn’t need a fully-functioning spacecraft or mission control to land on the moon. Instead, they installed LED screens and used in-camera effects to reach the final frontier. It was work which saw them pick up an Oscar earlier this year, its fourth in five years.

Now, just months after receiving widespread praise from critics for its work on Neil Armstrong biopic First Man, it seems the company has turned its attention to wooing a new crowd. Oscar critics may be tough to please, but, for DNEG, charming investors may prove equally testing.
